answers.author: Buffy Heslin
answers.text:
I am in the process of starting the new centralized call center for Hillsborough County and I am writing BPs (business policies) and SOP (standard operating procedures)...the primary thing to understand and develop in a logic tree when attempting to separate these items for me is what does the defined policy or procedure DO?  If its a policy its an expectation for a behavior, such as tardiness.  The HOW, if you will, of the way the business is run (think of an attendance policy) and the procedure would be the WHAT.  So for an attendance policy the expectation is that you are here x% of time and when you aren't then the impact is Z...the what would be that if you cannot be here you have to call and inform someone and fill out an absence sheet when you return indicating the time you are taking in-lieu of your scheduled hours.  Each function is a BP (policy) and the way its done is the SOP (procedure).

Also - my policies are static because they adhere to the civil service rules and HR guidelines but my procedures are dynamic and change as the scope and area of responsibility changes for the new call center.  Makes for ideal short updates and coverage with staff.

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is considering separating Policies from Procedures and creating two different documents.  They are interested in some “best practice” recommendations as to how to properly manage policies and procedures. The thinking is the separation of Policies from Procedures might facilitate employee understanding and simplify a periodic review process.
Your thoughts, ideas and documents are appreciated.
